Does anyone have any development experience with the new Java 
assertion mechanism 
in JDK 1.4?

I am having problems appreciating what additional value this 
mechanism brings to the
Java language.  The last project I was on applied many of the XP 
practices (test first,
unit testing).

When designing our classes, we would write tests (contracts) 
verifiying the functionality
of our classes.  If one practices this approach when developing, what 
additional benefit 
do assertions bring to the table?

This is the example I have been using:

Say we have a Math class with a sqrt routine.  We want to make it 
clear to the outside
world that our routine does not handle negative numbers.  If I were 
to write this class
today using standard Java mechanisms for argument checking, the 
method would look 
something like this:

public float sqrt(float number) {
	if (number < 0) {
	   throw IllegalArgumentException("Number can not be 
negative.");
	}
}

If we were to make this a precondition (ala Design By Contract) the 
assertion would look
something like:

public float sqrt(float number) {
	assert number < 0 : "Number can not be negative.";
}

Whats the difference?  Is one better then the other?

How is the 'assert' keyword affecting the code people are writing?

Jonathan
